results.title: John Davis
results.creator_credit: Robert Lindsay, Bob Weis, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Shows the work of Victorian sculptor John Davis, who uses many unusual materials and concepts to create modern sculpture

results.title: Rosalie Gascoigne
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Judi Stack, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Rosalie Gascoigne talks about her work and interests. She is a self-taught assemblage artist who uses weathered, discarded junk from man-made objects and found objects from nature. Her assemblages create images of domestic country kitchens while her late installations have an outdoor open feeling for country air and light
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Weis, Judi Stack, Robert Lindsay, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Robert Rooney
results.creator_credit: Bob Weis, Judi Stack, Robert Rooney, National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Robert Rooney’s art is a personal analysis of his own life, and in examining his own idiosyncratic behaviour he is exploring the routines and obsessions that concern each and every one of us. These routines are perhaps meaningless to some, yet they consume a major part of our everyday life

results.title: Stepping out: the birth of a theatre of the mentally handicapped
results.creator_credit: Chris Noonan and Binnaburra Film Company
results.brief_description: Sensitively explores the lives of a unique theatre group of intellectually handicapped people preparing for their first public performance at the Sydney Opera House. Two members of the group, Chris 31 and Romayne 21, who have lived in the institution since early childhood express their attitudes to each other, their lives and hopes for the future. This film was chosen as the film for the International Year of the Disabled by the United Nations. Music: Keith Jarrett Camera: Dean Semler.

results.title: Listen to a city
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, Andrew J. Helgeson and Cinesound
results.brief_description: A sophisticated view of Melbourne taking in its gardens, shops, theatres, restaurants, nightclubs and discotheques. Sporting activities include a race meeting, a football match, and water sports. Highlights Melbourne’s annual Moombe Festival and includes scenes at Montsalvat.

results.title: First Fleet: rite of passage
results.creator_credit: Bill Leimbach, Michael Balson, Richard Dennison, First Fleet Re-enactment Company and Orana Films
results.brief_description: Produced to commemorate Australia’s Bicentenary (1988), this video captures the official First Fleet Reenactment Voyage in 200 minutes of action and adventure. Witness the trials and tribulations of the modern day voyagers who took part in the voyage from Portsmouth on 13 May 1987 to the spectacular finale on Sydney Harbour on Australia Day, 26 January 1988.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Leimbach, Michael Balson, Richard Dennison, First Fleet Re-enactment Company and Orana Films

results.title: The Bad society
results.brief_description: In December 1976, 16,000 people converged at the Cotter River in Canberra for the “Down to earth” festival; a conference on alternative lifestyles. In attendance were Reverend George Davies, Dr. Jim Cairns, Dr. Jim Falk as well as thousands of counter culture followers. This documentary explores the festival and the themes of politics and social change. The Philisophy of Ex Deputy Prime Minister, Dr. Jim Cairns is particularly focussed on with its emphasis on how a nation state creates a ‘bad society’ and how communal life and a counter culture lifestyle forms the only radicalism against society.

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.

results.title: Australia, Where Time Began
results.brief_description: Ravaged by time, wind, water and a scorching sun, the world’s most extraordinary landscape has evolved - a landscape of contrast, mystery and awe. This film is an explanation of how the deserts, salt lakes, monoliths, escarpments and gorges of the planet’s only island continent were created. It also portrays the endearing animals and plants which have adapted to an often hostile environment.

results.title: Life in the Desert
results.brief_description: The viewer is taken into the Australian desert and shown the amazing variety of plants and animals and informed how they manage to survive in such extreme conditions.
